entry.title: Nathaniel Meyer liked the topic named DewDrop Utility Scripts in the DewDrop forum.
entry.summary:
I started a CodeCloud project to store scripts that I've found useful for working with DewDrop. This project should be viewable/cloneable by anyone with access to CodeCloud.

I've been using these scripts to handle tasks that I've found to be either tricky to get correct (like installing SWM) or need to be repeated enough that whipping up a script was useful (like reconfiguring the networking when my VPN-assigned hostname changes each time I reconnect).

Some things to keep in mind:

  • The scripts are pretty solid but more basic documentation is needed.
  • The provided alternative to the 'Pers.cmd' (that is packaged with DewDrop) is named 'ddctl.sh' and is intended to be used by Apple OSX users wanting to use DewDrop. Beyond being bash-friendly, it handles some additional manipulation of the VirtualBox VM settings that make it easier to use in a VPN environment , sets up Port-Forwarding for SSH access to the VM and makes it easy to launch a 'headless' DewDrop VM.
  • Feedback, enhancements and bug fixes are welcome

object.summary:
I started a CodeCloud project to store scripts that I've found useful for working with DewDrop. This project should be viewable/cloneable by anyone with access to CodeCloud.

I've been using these scripts to handle tasks that I've found to be either tricky to get correct (like installing SWM) or need to be repeated enough that whipping up a script was useful (like reconfiguring the networking when my VPN-assigned hostname changes each time I reconnect).

Some things to keep in mind:

  • The scripts are pretty solid but more basic documentation is needed.
  • The provided alternative to the 'Pers.cmd' (that is packaged with DewDrop) is named 'ddctl.sh' and is intended to be used by Apple OSX users wanting to use DewDrop. Beyond being bash-friendly, it handles some additional manipulation of the VirtualBox VM settings that make it easier to use in a VPN environment , sets up Port-Forwarding for SSH access to the VM and makes it easy to launch a 'headless' DewDrop VM.
  • Feedback, enhancements and bug fixes are welcome

activityEntry.title: Nathaniel Meyer liked the topic named DewDrop Utility Scripts in the DewDrop forum.

entry.title: Martin P McEnroe replied to the AT&T URL Shortener, now with Vanity Aliases! topic thread in the General Topics Forum forum.
entry.summary:
You mean like this?

 

link.att.com/MrHandsome

object.displayName: Re: AT&T URL Shortener, now with Vanity Aliases!
object.summary:
You mean like this?

 

link.att.com/MrHandsome

target.displayName: AT&T URL Shortener, now with Vanity Aliases!
target.summary:
Did you know that AT&T has its very own URL Shortener?  One that works for internal URL's and supports 'vanity' short links?

An example of what this does for you would be:

  • You have a tSpace Community, which tend to expose a long and difficult to remember URL: 
    https://tspace.web.att.com/communities/service/html/communitystart?communityUuid=553bd02e-c8c2-4aa8-9bf0-93630920652d
  • You go to Canary Shorten and create an alias for that address:
    ' DataNightLive '
  • Canary Shorten creates a shortened link that resolves to your tSpace Community and is much nicer to share with others (not to mention easier to remember):
    http://link.att.com/DataNightLive

If you don't really care to create a vanity alias, you can also let Canary Shorten generate the alias for you.

Go to Canary Shorten and give it a try!

activityEntry.title: Martin P McEnroe replied to the AT&T URL Shortener, now with Vanity Aliases! topic thread in the General Topics Forum forum.

entry.title: James H Pratt replied to the Safari client cert required to access tspace topic thread in the Mac Support forum.
entry.summary:
Yes, I have it. i just hit cancel and it goes away for that tab.

 

In the past, I've tried to delete the Key Access certificate and it has required the certificate, but it "came back" after "some use".

 

Similar problems as this:

http://apple.stackexchange.com/questions/94379/safari-not-accepting-website-certificate

object.displayName: Re: Safari client cert required to access tspace
object.summary:
Yes, I have it. i just hit cancel and it goes away for that tab.

 

In the past, I've tried to delete the Key Access certificate and it has required the certificate, but it "came back" after "some use".

 

Similar problems as this:

http://apple.stackexchange.com/questions/94379/safari-not-accepting-website-certificate

target.displayName: Safari client cert required to access tspace
target.summary: Is anyone else having issues with Safari connecting to tspace?  When I try to connect to most any tspace page, I get an error when using Safari.  The error indicates that Safari is lacking a client certificate to present to tspace for authentication.  I don't get this same error with Chrome or Firefox.  When I get the error, sometimes the page loads and sometimes it does not, but it always pops up this really annoying dialog box asking for the correct client certificate.  If anyone else has run into this issue and resolved it within Safari, I would love to know what the solution is.  Yes, I can use Chrome or Firefox, but I primarily use Safari and don't want to switch primary browsers if I don't have to.

activityEntry.title: James H Pratt replied to the Safari client cert required to access tspace topic thread in the Mac Support forum.

entry.title: Bill Knotts commented on a file.
entry.summary:
Hi Wesley -

This file extension requires Freeplane (a 'mind map' application). You can get Freeplane by following the 'How to Acquire' info at the bottom of this page - http://tss.att.com/detail.cfm?product_id=6648

Or you could grab it directly from the Freeplane site (but you didn't hear that from me...)
